botanical.title: Purple Spotted Flowering Plant
botanical.name: Foxglove
botanical.description: A tall flowering plant with tubular flowers in shades of pink, purple, white, or yellow. Known for its distinctive spotted throats. Native to Europe but grown worldwide. Contains cardiac-active compounds historically used in medicine.
botanical.purpose: The murder weapon - added by Dr. Thaddeus to corrupt the elixir
botanical.location: Concentrated extract in abandoned garage / residue in glass bottle
botanical.reveals: Concentrated extract that was added to Sebastian's harmless formula. Caused cumulative cardiac poisoning in both Cordelia and Sebastian. Fatal in high doses.
botanical.symptoms: Weakness, nausea, confusion, vision problems, cardiac distress, heart failure

character_interpretations.professor: Foxglove—Digitalis purpurea. The cardiac glycosides require extraction and concentration, a process showing significant botanical knowledge. Someone consulted about extraction methods. Someone prepared this deliberately, not accidentally. Whoever did this knew exactly what they were doing.
character_interpretations.baker: There's a plant that grows in the garden, tall with purple and white spotted flowers. Pretty, really. I've seen it around estate gardens. But I'd never use it in cooking—I know from intuition it's dangerous. Something about it just feels... wrong.
character_interpretations.heiress: There are plants all over this estate I've never bothered to identify. Some are quite beautiful, honestly. That tall purple-flowered one with the spotted throats is striking. I should ask the gardener what it's called.
character_interpretations.explorer: I've seen this plant in various gardens around the world. Common in European estates. Tall, sturdy, grows in clusters. Not something most people would notice unless they're looking for it.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: My toxicology hobby includes knowing about botanical poisons. Foxglove is one of the most famous—digitalis compounds, cardiac glycosides, dangerous in any concentration. If someone was interested in this plant, that's a significant red flag.

botanical.title: Tropical Yellow Flower Specimen
botanical.name: Damiana
botanical.description: A small tropical shrub with delicate yellow flowers. Native to Mexico and Central America. Has a minty, slightly bitter flavor. Traditionally used in herbal beverages and infusions.
botanical.purpose: Original ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Legitimate ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir. Non-toxic in small doses. Proves Sebastian's formula was designed to be harmless.

character_interpretations.professor: Damiana—Turnera diffusa. I can identify it by the dried leaf structure. Tropical origin, requires warm climate cultivation. This is sophisticated sourcing.
character_interpretations.baker: I can identify this from dried herb suppliers. Damiana has a distinctive smell—slightly minty, slightly bitter. Someone knew what they were sourcing.
character_interpretations.heiress: I don't spend time in abandoned garages examining bottles of dried plant matter.
character_interpretations.explorer: Dried damiana leaves. The processing is careful—the leaves are intact, properly dried. Whoever prepared this knew what they were doing.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: Damiana. Completely harmless. Non-toxic, traditional medicinal use. Just an ingredient, nothing suspicious about it.

botanical.title: Dried Earthen Root Powder
botanical.name: Valerian Root
botanical.description: The dried root of Valeriana officinalis. Has a distinctive earthy, musty aroma. Used in traditional herbal preparations for centuries. Often combined with other herbs in formulations.
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Legitimate ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir. Safe sedative herb. Chosen to calm the bride and create intimacy.

character_observations.professor: Valeriana officinalis root. Dried, ground to powder. The earthiness is unmistakable. Prepared by someone who knew traditional herbal methods.
character_observations.baker: I know valerian by smell. Earthy, musty, distinctive. The grinding is fine—consistent preparation. Whoever made this knew herbalism.
character_observations.heiress: I don't examine jars in dark garages.
character_observations.explorer: Properly harvested and dried valerian root. The preparation shows knowledge—roots were dug at the right season, dried correctly. Not casual collection.
character_observations.fiduciary: Valerian root. Completely safe. Standard herbal preparation. No toxicological concerns whatsoever.

botanical.title: Precious Forked Root Specimen
botanical.name: Ginseng Root
botanical.description: The precious root of the ginseng plant. Has a distinctive forked, human-like shape. Highly prized in Eastern traditions and alchemical practices. Symbolizes vitality, longevity, and spiritual connection—perfect for binding eternal love.
botanical.purpose: Original ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Alchemical 'binding' agent with mystical significance. Symbolic rather than pharmacologically significant. Shows Sebastian's romantic, mystical approach to the formula.

character_observations.professor: Ginseng root—precious, difficult to source. The fact that this is here shows significant botanical knowledge and expense. Not someone casually dabbling in herbalism.
character_observations.baker: I don't recognize this root. The shape is unusual. Looks ancient, ritualistic. Out of my knowledge.
character_observations.heiress: I don't spend time examining curiosities in abandoned garages.
character_observations.explorer: A genuine ginseng root. Very difficult to cultivate and expensive. Only serious practitioners would source this. Someone went to significant effort and considerable expense.
character_observations.fiduciary: Ginseng root. Prized in Eastern traditions and magical practices. Completely harmless. But its presence is... unusual and costly.

botanical.title: Precious Floral Essential Oil
botanical.name: Rose Otto
botanical.description: A precious essential oil extracted from rose petals. One of the most expensive oils in the world. Has a deep, complex floral aroma. Requires hundreds of rose flowers to produce a small amount.
botanical.purpose: Original ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Precious essential oil sacred to Venus (the planet and goddess). Shows the romantic significance of the elixir.

character_observations.professor: Rose Otto. The fragrance alone identifies it. A few drops would cost more than most people's weekly food budget. The oil is pure, not cut or adulterated.
character_observations.baker: Rose Otto. I recognize the smell immediately. This is extremely expensive—only high-end work uses this. Someone was serious about creating something luxurious.
character_observations.heiress: I don't examine bottles in garages.
character_observations.explorer: Pure rose oil. The color and consistency are right—this is genuine Ottoman or Bulgarian distillation. Not an imitation. Someone paid dearly for this.
character_observations.fiduciary: Rose Otto. Non-toxic, of course. But the cost alone tells a story. This was expensive sourcing. Someone with money.

botanical.title: White Crystalline Powder
botanical.name: Potassium Bromide
botanical.description: A crystalline chemical compound used in pharmaceutical preparations. Once common in medical formulations during the 1920s. Appears as white crystals or powder.
botanical.purpose: Original ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Legitimate medical compound used as mild sedative in 1920s. Safe in small doses. Shows Sebastian's knowledge of both traditional and modern medicine.

character_interpretations.professor: Potassium bromide. White crystalline powder. A pharmaceutical compound, not botanical. Shows someone knew modern medicine, not just plant lore.
character_interpretations.baker: A white powder in a jar. I have no idea what it is. Not my field.
character_interpretations.heiress: I don't examine mysterious powders in garages.
character_interpretations.explorer: A pharmaceutical—potassium bromide. The crystals are well-formed, properly stored. Someone was mixing modern pharmaceuticals with botanical ingredients. Interesting combination.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: Potassium bromide. A documented 1920s pharmaceutical. Non-toxic in prescribed amounts. Common in the era.
character_interpretations.doctor: Potassium bromide. A mild sedative used in 1920s medical practice. Safe in prescribed doses. Shows someone was blending traditional herbal knowledge with established pharmaceutical compounds for a holistic approach.

botanical.title: Fine White Powder
botanical.name: Calcium Lactate
botanical.description: A salt of lactic acid, calcium lactate is a common ingredient in dietary supplements and laxatives. It's often used to improve absorption of calcium and as a mild laxative.
botanical.purpose: Original ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Fortifying/health tonic. Shows Sebastian's intention to strengthen Cordelia.

character_interpretations.professor: Calcium lactate. Another pharmaceutical powder. Someone combining botanicals with modern nutritional supplements. Strategic approach.
character_interpretations.baker: Another unidentified powder. Chemistry work, not baking.
character_interpretations.heiress: More mysterious jars. I'm not interested.
character_interpretations.explorer: Calcium lactate. A fortifying supplement common in 1920s health tonics. Shows deliberate health supplementation alongside the botanical work.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: Calcium lactate. Safe, nutritional. Common in 1920s supplements. Nothing suspicious.
character_interpretations.doctor: Calcium lactate. Used medically to improve calcium absorption. An excellent choice for fortification, particularly for women preparing for significant life changes. Shows careful attention to health optimization.

botanical.title: Reddish-Brown Powder
botanical.name: Iron Citrate
botanical.description: A form of iron, iron citrate is used to treat iron deficiency anemia. It's also a common ingredient in dietary supplements.
botanical.purpose: Original ingredient in Sebastian's harmless elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Iron tonic to enrich blood and boost vitality. Shows Sebastian's intent to strengthen Cordelia for the marriage ahead.

character_interpretations.professor: Iron citrate. A bioavailable form of iron. Again, mixing botanicals with pharmaceuticals. Someone with real knowledge of health supplementation.
character_interpretations.baker: More powder. I can't identify this.
character_interpretations.heiress: I've lost interest in the jars.
character_interpretations.explorer: Iron citrate. Another 1920s supplement. Health tonics were standard practice—someone was thorough in preparation.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: Iron citrate. A standard tonic of the era. Non-toxic, intended for health. No concerns.
character_interpretations.doctor: Iron citrate. An excellent form of iron for treating anemia. Particularly valuable for women, as iron deficiency was common before pregnancy. Shows thoughtful care for Cordelia's wellbeing and health.

botanical.title: Sweet Amber Syrup Mixture
botanical.name: Vanilla, Cherry Syrup, Honey
botanical.description: A sweet, aromatic combination of vanilla, cherry, and honey. Often used as a natural sweetener and flavoring agent. Cherry syrup is derived from tart cherries.
botanical.purpose: Taste and preservation in Sebastian's elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: Sweet flavorings that made the elixir palatable. Disguised the taste of botanicals.

character_interpretations.professor: Vanilla extract, cherry syrup, honey. Flavorings. These mask the taste of the botanicals. Smart choice—herbal preparations are unpalatable without sweetening.
character_interpretations.baker: I recognize these flavors immediately. Good quality vanilla, proper cherry syrup, real honey. Someone cared about taste balance. These would disguise herbal bitterness well.
character_interpretations.heiress: I don't spend time examining jars of syrup in garages.
character_interpretations.explorer: Vanilla, cherry syrup, honey. The vanilla smells genuine, the syrup is well-made. These are quality ingredients. Someone wasn't cutting corners on flavor.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: Common flavorings. Their purpose is obvious—to make herbal preparations palatable. Nothing suspicious.

botanical.title: Clear High-Proof Spirit
botanical.name: Grain Alcohol 95%
botanical.description: A clear, colorless distilled spirit with high alcohol content. Used historically as a base and preservative in herbal preparations and tinctures. Burns with a blue flame.
botanical.purpose: Base and preservative for the elixir
botanical.location: Ingredient in a bottle in the garage
botanical.reveals: High-proof alcohol used as base and preservative during Prohibition era (illicit source).

character_interpretations.professor: 95% grain alcohol. An excellent solvent and preservative. High proof shows serious work—someone wasn't making amateur tinctures.
character_interpretations.baker: Strong spirits. Much stronger than anything I work with. Professional-grade alcohol.
character_interpretations.heiress: I don't examine bottles of illegal spirits.
character_interpretations.explorer: Pure grain alcohol during Prohibition? Someone had serious underworld connections. This wasn't casual sourcing—this was expensive and connected.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: 95% grain alcohol. Likely illicit during Prohibition. Someone had access to bootleggers or illegal suppliers. This wasn't acquired legally.

botanical.title: Collection of Preserved Plant Samples
botanical.name: Plant Specimens in Jars
botanical.description: A collection of preserved plant specimens, including foxglove, herbs, and exotic plants, found in the abandoned garage at Montrose Mansion. These specimens demonstrate Sebastian's botanical knowledge and his meticulous research methods.
botanical.location: Abandoned Garage at Montrose Mansion
botanical.reveals: Sebastian's preserved plant samples including foxglove, herbs, and exotic specimens. Shows his botanical expertise and research methods.

character_interpretations.professor: An entire collection of preserved specimens. This shows systematic botanical study—not random gathering. The preservation methods are careful, the organization is methodical. Someone was conducting serious botanical research, cataloging plants and their properties. This is the work of someone with significant botanical knowledge.
character_interpretations.baker: Jars of dried plants. I recognize some of them, but I don't know all of them. Someone was definitely collecting and studying these carefully.
character_interpretations.heiress: A collection of odd jars. I don't know what most of these are.
character_interpretations.explorer: Preserved botanical specimens. The organization and care taken in preservation shows serious study. Someone was building a reference collection.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: Multiple plant specimens preserved. This is evidence of deliberate botanical research and experimentation.

botanical.title: Leather-Bound Reference Volume
botanical.name: Herb Encyclopedia - 1920s Edition
botanical.location: Montrose mansion library, dusty shelf
botanical.description: A water-stained leather-bound volume, likely from the 1920s, containing handwritten annotations in the margins. It's an encyclopedia of medicinal and botanical knowledge, with notes in Sebastian's handwriting on romantic herbs, aphrodisiacs, and love magic.
botanical.reveals: Encyclopedia with extensive annotations in Sebastian's handwriting. Notes mark pages on romantic herbs, aphrodisiacs, and botanical research. Shows his careful study of ingredients for the elixir formula.

character_interpretations.professor: This handwriting—meticulous notes in margins. Someone studied this book carefully. The annotations are detailed, systematic. Shows real research, not casual interest.
character_interpretations.baker: A library book with notes. I can't read all the technical annotations, but the fact that someone marked it up tells me they were studying it seriously.
character_interpretations.heiress: A dusty old book. I found this in the library and haven't read through it thoroughly. It looks important though.
character_interpretations.explorer: Detailed annotations on botanical and alchemical knowledge. Someone was doing serious research before preparing the elixir. This shows planning.
character_interpretations.fiduciary: A reference book with extensive marginalia. The handwriting is consistent, methodical. Someone was using this as a research guide, taking it seriously.

botanical.title: Purple Fragrant Garden Plant
botanical.name: Lavender Plant
botanical.description: A well-maintained lavender plant, a symbol of peace and calm. It's a gardener's favorite for its soothing aroma, but has no direct connection to the poison or crime.
botanical.location: Montrose garden, fragrant corner
botanical.reveals: Ancient symbol of peace and calm. Gardener's favorite for its soothing aroma. No mystery significance - just a lovely garden plant.

character_interpretations.professor: Lavender. Common Mediterranean herb. Well-maintained, aromatic. A staple in garden and kitchen. Its soothing properties make it a natural choice for relaxation and stress relief.
character_interpretations.baker: Lavender. The scent is lovely. Someone tends this garden carefully.
character_interpretations.heiress: This corner smells wonderful. Lavender was my great-aunt's favorite. I've been letting the gardens grow wild, but this one thrives anyway.
character_interpretations.explorer: Lavender. Well-established plant, clearly years old. The garden was maintained at some point, though it's neglected now.

botanical.title: Grey-Green Needled Herb Plant
botanical.name: Rosemary Plant
botanical.description: A fragrant grey-green needled plant with tiny purple flowers, a common garden herb. Research notes show Dr. Thaddeus studied rosemary as potential cardiac support, written in his private research notes from 1925.
botanical.location: Montrose garden, herb section
botanical.reveals: Found growing in the Montrose garden herb section. Research notes show Dr. Thaddeus studied rosemary as potential cardiac support, written in his private research notes from 1925. Rosemary contains powerful antioxidants and circulatory benefits. Shows Thaddeus was researching cardiac support plants.

character_interpretations.professor: Rosemary. Common herb, excellent circulatory properties. Good choice if someone was trying to help a cardiac patient.
character_interpretations.baker: Rosemary from the garden. Fragrant, strong flavor. A helpful herb.
character_interpretations.heiress: Rosemary grows wild here. I didn't know it was medicinal.
character_interpretations.explorer: Rosemary. Mediterranean origin, grows reliably in this climate. Been here for years.

botanical.title: Delicate Purple-Flowered Herb
botanical.name: Thyme
botanical.description: A delicate green herb with tiny purple flowers, a traditional culinary herb. It's found growing in the Montrose garden herb section, but has no direct connection to the poison or crime.
botanical.location: Montrose garden, near rosemary
botanical.reveals: Traditional culinary herb, the 'herb of courage.' Found growing in the Montrose garden herb section. No mystery significance - just an elegant garden touch.

character_interpretations.professor: Thyme. Common Mediterranean herb. A culinary staple, aromatic, and versatile. Its mild, slightly bitter flavor and purple flowers make it a popular choice for cooking and herbal remedies.
character_interpretations.baker: Thyme from the garden. Useful in cooking. Its strong, aromatic flavor adds depth to dishes.
character_interpretations.heiress: Tiny purple flowers. Pretty. Its delicate appearance and pleasant aroma make it a charming addition to any garden.
character_interpretations.explorer: Thyme. Mediterranean, hardy plant. Grows well in this climate. Its aromatic leaves and purple flowers are a common sight in Mediterranean gardens.

botanical.title: Overgrown Stinging Plant Patch
botanical.name: Stinging Nettle
botanical.description: An overgrown patch of stinging nettle, a plant known for its strong, stinging hairs. It's found in an old gardener's log, which mentions its potential cardiac benefits.
botanical.location: Edge of Montrose garden, wild corner
botanical.reveals: Found in old gardener's log: 'High in compounds that strengthen cardiac tissue.' Dr. Thaddeus ordered nettle tea during this period. Shows his interest in cardiac support botanicals.

character_interpretations.professor: Stinging nettle. Common medicinal herb. High mineral content, circulatory benefits. Its stinging hairs are a natural defense mechanism, but its roots contain compounds that can be beneficial for cardiac health.
character_interpretations.baker: Nettle. Good for tea. Medicinal. Its bitter, astringent flavor makes it a popular choice for herbal remedies.
character_interpretations.heiress: Stinging plants. Better to avoid. Its strong, stinging hairs can be painful.
character_interpretations.explorer: Nettle patch. Wild, established. Used to be intentional cultivation. Its strong, stinging hairs are a natural defense mechanism, but its roots can be used for medicinal purposes.

botanical.title: White and Yellow Flowered Plant
botanical.name: Chamomile
botanical.description: Cheerful white and yellow flowers, dried bundles hanging nearby, a common garden staple. It's dried and bundled in the Montrose mansion kitchen, but has no direct connection to the poison or crime.
botanical.location: Montrose garden, near house
botanical.reveals: Soothing garden staple found in the Montrose mansion kitchen, dried and bundled. Chamomile was commonly used for calming teas during the 1920s. No mystery connection - just a beloved household herb and comforting ritual of the era.

character_interpretations.professor: Chamomile. Common, harmless. A gentle, soothing herb. Its delicate, daisy-like flowers and mild flavor make it a popular choice for calming teas and skin care.
character_interpretations.baker: Chamomile. Used for tea. Kitchen herb. Its mild, slightly sweet flavor and calming properties make it a staple in herbal preparations.
character_interpretations.heiress: White flowers. Pretty dried. Its delicate, daisy-like appearance and pleasant aroma make it a popular choice for dried floral arrangements.
character_interpretations.explorer: Chamomile. Old bundles, dried properly. Its delicate, daisy-like flowers and mild flavor make it a common sight in gardens and kitchens.

botanical.title: Tan Root Pieces in Jar
botanical.name: Ginger Root
botanical.description: Dried ginger root in labeled glass jar, faded label, a common kitchen spice. It's used in teas for upset stomachs and digestive comfort during the 1920s, but has no direct connection to the poison or crime.
botanical.location: Montrose kitchen, spice shelf
botanical.reveals: Found among the Montrose kitchen spices. Ginger was used in teas for upset stomachs and digestive comfort during the 1920s. No mystery connection, just a reminder of common household remedies of the era.

character_interpretations.professor: Ginger. Digestive spice. A common kitchen staple. Its spicy, warm flavor and warming properties make it a popular choice for digestive discomfort and warming teas.
character_interpretations.baker: Ginger. Kitchen spice. Common. Its strong, spicy flavor and warming properties make it a popular choice for cooking and herbal remedies.
character_interpretations.heiress: Spice jar. Old label. Its strong, spicy flavor and warming properties make it a common ingredient in kitchen remedies.
character_interpretations.explorer: Dried ginger. Well-preserved. Its strong, spicy flavor and warming properties make it a common ingredient in kitchen remedies.

botanical.title: Dried Herb Bundle
botanical.name: Sage
botanical.description: A bundled dried sage tied with string, likely used for spiritual cleansing and meditation. It's found in Alice's room, but has no direct connection to the poison or crime.
botanical.location: Alice's room, shelf near window
botanical.reveals: Alice used sage for spiritual cleansing and meditation. No connection to the poison or crime. Shows Alice's spiritual practices and her search for peace and clarity in the mansion's darkness.

character_interpretations.professor: Dried sage. Aromatic herb. A common spiritual and medicinal herb. Its strong, aromatic smoke is used for purification and meditation.
character_interpretations.baker: Sage bundle. For cleansing, I'd guess. Its strong, aromatic smoke is used for purification and meditation.
character_interpretations.heiress: Something spiritual. Alice's things. Its strong, aromatic smoke is used for purification and meditation.
character_interpretations.explorer: Sage bundle, ceremonial preparation. Its strong, aromatic smoke is used for purification and meditation.

botanical.title: Colorful Fruiting Garden Plants
botanical.name: Spicy Peppers
botanical.description: Thriving pepper plants with vibrant red, yellow, and green peppers; varieties labeled as jalapeño, habanero, and serrano, a common garden vegetable. Various hot pepper varieties suggest the household chef enjoyed culinary experimentation and bold flavors, but has no direct connection to the poison or crime.
botanical.location: Montrose garden, kitchen vegetable section
botanical.reveals: Found thriving in the Montrose mansion's vegetable garden section. Various hot pepper varieties suggest the household chef enjoyed culinary experimentation and bold flavors. No mystery significance - just evidence of the mansion's sophisticated kitchen and adventurous tastes.

character_interpretations.professor: Pepper plants. Culinary varieties. A common garden vegetable. Its pungent, spicy flavor and vibrant colors make it a popular choice for culinary experimentation and bold dishes.
character_interpretations.baker: Jalapeño, habanero, serrano. Chef liked heat. Its strong, spicy flavor and vibrant colors make it a popular choice for bold flavors.
character_interpretations.heiress: Colorful vegetables. Still growing. Its strong, spicy flavor and vibrant colors make it a common sight in gardens.
character_interpretations.explorer: Multiple pepper varieties. Intentional planting. Its strong, spicy flavor and vibrant colors make it a common sight in gardens.
